A glimpse into some python tools I have learned in my Computational Biology course. 

# R and Python

Reticulate package allows R and Python to interact with each other. 

```{R}
# R code
library(reticulate)
la<-"indian"
```

```{python}
# Python code
import re 
la="blanket"
```

```{R}
# R code: access R-defined objects with r
cat(c(la,py$la))
```

```{python}
# Python code: access Python-defined objects with py$
print(r.la,la)
```

# Regular Expressions (regex)

Regular Expressions search for defined patterns in a block of text.

```{python}
import re 
```

```{python}
# Match restriction enzyme binding sites ANTAAT and GCRWTG. Note that per the IUPAC nucleotide code, N is any base, R is A or G, W is A or T.

string1=""

re.findall(r"A[ATGC]TAAT",string1)
re.findall(r"GC[AG][AT]TG",string1)
```

Besides Reticulate, other useful python packages that we touched on include NumPy, pandas, Matplotlib, and Seaborn.
